When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a cook .
It even rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regent in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the carbon knoll is taken away with diligent , unwashed hands and swallowed .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also performs her daily work , such as washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , no fields were assigned .

Of course , late work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 17 o 'clock ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was included in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders should vote by public hiding before the occupying forces .

An existing movement that stimulated independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which maintains control over the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea including the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is tired ; the journey includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and then a morning 5-hour rental car .
There is no public transport .
The city of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated sheet roofs converted into different yellow brown tones by rust .
Only a few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans revered a god called Uga Tamee .

We were not used to wearing this clothing ,  says Degei and points to her lively , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .

Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s Goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is just 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
